awd_titl_txt: Neural mechanisms for phonological alternation with high and low productivity - a case study on tone sandhi
awd_abstract_narration:
Of the 7,000 or so languages spoken in the world today, a conservative estimate of around half of them are tonal, in that the use of pitch itself may change the meaning of a word. This list includes languages that play key roles in the economy and national security of the US such as Chinese and Vietnamese as well as many Native American languages such as Navajo and Cherokee. A better understanding of the linguistic properties of these languages is a meaningful first step in increasing the communication efficiency with speakers of these languages and the development of better learning materials for these languages for native speakers of English. This project investigates the linguistic patterns of tone in two Chinese languages--Mandarin and Taiwanese--using state-of-the-art neurolinguistic techniques to shed light on how words with tones are represented in the speakers' brains. It contributes methodological innovations that will allow the different stages of the production processing of tone to be tracked by neurological measures. Moreover, this project involves international collaboration between a US institution and two prominent neurolinguistic laboratories in Hong Kong and Taiwan. The established connections will provide educational opportunities for students both in the US and internationally.
 
This project focuses on tonal alternation patterns whereby a tone takes different phonological forms in different contexts, also known as "tone sandhi." Behavioral studies have shown that tone sandhi patterns extend to novel words in different ways, i.e., have different productivity, depending on the phonological nature of the pattern. This suggests that different mechanisms may be involved in the processing of this type of phonological alternation. This project uses event-related potentials (ERPs) to examine the time-course of the encoding of a number of tone sandhi patterns in Mandarin and Taiwanese in speech production. It is hypothesized that unproductive sandhi patterns are primarily subserved by a lexical mechanism that engages neural activities in an earlier time window of lexical retrieval (approximately 150-225 ms after the initiation of production), while productive sandhi patterns are primarily subserved by a computation mechanism that engages neural activities in a later time-window of phonological encoding (400-600 ms). It is also hypothesized that the neural activities of the lexical mechanism are sensitive to lexical frequency, while those of the computation mechanism are less so. This project will be the first to investigate the neural activities underlying the putative computation vs. lexical mechanisms associated with productive and unproductive phonological alternations. The increased understanding of the neural encoding of phonological alternation will inform both the theoretical models of speech production and formal models of phonological competence. Findings of this project can also be linked to issues of morphological decompositionality such as regularity and semantic transparency to achieve a fuller understanding of the neural bases of linguistic productivity.

por.por_cntn:
More than half of the 7,000 or so languages spoken in the world today are tonal, in that the use of pitch itself may change the meaning of a word. These languages include those that play key roles in the economy and national security of the US such as Chinese and Vietnamese as well as many Native American languages such as Navajo and Cherokee. This project used electroencephalography (EEG) to shed light on how tones are processed in the speakers’ brains as they pronounce words in tone languages. In particular, we compared tone processing in two important Chinese languages — Mandarin and Taiwanese Southern Min — that have very different linguistic properties in their tone patterns. Both of these languages have a type of tone pattern called “tone sandhi,” whereby a tone changes (from a “base tone” to a “sandhi tone”) according to the linguistic context that it appears in. Mandarin’s tone sandhi pattern is “productive,” in that it can be easily extended to novel words that come into the language; Taiwanese Southern Min’s tone sandhi pattern, on the other hand, is largely “unproductive,” meaning that novel words often do not take on the tone sandhi pattern that native words exhibit. We tested the hypothesis that tone sandhi patterns with different productivity are processed with different neural mechanisms: productive patterns are primarily processed by a computation mechanism, which computes the sandhi tone from its base tone according to the context that it appears in; unproductive patterns are primarily processed by a lexical mechanism, which retrieves the stored sandhi tone from memory. In a set of experiments that used event-related potentials (ERPs) to examine the time-course of tone sandhi processing during speech production, we found strong support for our hypothesis. The production of Mandarin tone sandhi engages a base tone to sandhi tone computation indexed by an ERP component that coincides with the time window of phonological and phonetic encoding; it is facilitated (primed) by a previously heard syllable with the base tone, with the priming effect indexed by a similarly timed ERP component. For the production of Taiwanese Southern Min tone sandhi, on the other hand, we only observed significant priming from the sandhi tone in the ERP, indicating direct retrieval of the sandhi tone without mediation from the base tone. Additional experiments on the recognition of Mandarin tone sandhi words and the production of Mandarin tone sandhi words with added cognitive demands provided further support for the computation mechanism for Mandarin tone sandhi. This is the first study to investigate and contrast the neural activities underlying productive and unproductive phonological patterns. It contributes to our understanding of productivity — a key property in the typology of human language. It also contributes to our understanding of the neural encoding of phonological patterns in general, and consequently, informs both the theoretical models of speech production and formal models of phonological competence.

This project involved collaborative effort from institutions around the globe (University of Kansas, Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Taiwan Academia Sinica). This is in fact the first collaboration between the US National Science Foundation and Hong Kong Polytechnic University. The established connections can facilitate further research collaborations among these institutions. The project provided educational opportunities for research assistants, students, and postdocs both in the US and internationally. A graduate student from Hong Kong Polytechnic University spent a semester at the University of Kansas as a Visiting Scholar. Research findings from the project were incorporated into course materials that benefited both undergraduate and graduate students at the University of Kansas. As an outreach effort of the project, an “International Workshop on the Neurolinguistic Studies of Tone” was held at Hong Kong Polytechnic University as part of a four-week summer school on “Language, Cognition, and Neuroscience,” where participants from the US, Hong Kong, Taiwan, and mainland China shared research findings, discussed collaborative and educational opportunities, and envisioned the future development of the field.
